text:
I'd like to add the benefits of "strolling" (any better word?) meaning to look around into different corners to learn and discover things. I really want to push back on the focus on maximum productivity.. when tinkering / strolling is fun and beneficial.
Sure you can get the LLM to order pizza and have a full stomach in half an hour.. but Isn't life about taking unexpected detours, try new things and enjoying the path and people to get there?
Now that I think of it, I actually use LLMs often for strolling into areas I'm not very familiar.. sort of a talk with a senior at the water cooler.

Sure you can get the LLM to order pizza and have a full stomach in half an hour.. but Isn't life about taking unexpected detours, try new things and enjoying the path and people to get there?
Now that I think of it, I actually use LLMs often for strolling into areas I'm not very familiar.. sort of a talk with a senior at the water cooler.

text: <@U07BD7U4S4R> I seem to misunderstand. I'm trying to reverse engineer what you're thinking. In my world Lisp has always, since 1956, been about tree oriented programming. The Lisp reader reads characters from a file and turns them into linked lists and then processes the linked lists. In my mind Clojure isn't lisp. Clojure is just functional programming with lisp-y syntax instead of Javascript-y syntax. <https://programmingsimplicity.substack.com/p/on-programming-paradigms?r=1egdky|... more thoughts ...>

elements.text: I seem to misunderstand. I'm trying to reverse engineer what you're thinking. In my world Lisp has always, since 1956, been about tree oriented programming. The Lisp reader reads characters from a file and turns them into linked lists and then processes the linked lists. In my mind Clojure isn't lisp. Clojure is just functional programming with lisp-y syntax instead of Javascript-y syntax.
